Class ec.util.ObjKeyTable

Class ec.util.ObjKeyTable 

java.lang.Object
   |
   +----ec.util.ObjKeyTable
public class ObjKeyTable
extends Object
implements Cloneable
ObjKeyTable class. Maps keys to values. Any object can be used as a key, but the values are ints.

To successfully store and retrieve objects from a hash table, the object used as the key must implement the hashCode() methods.

The 'useEquals' construction argument determines whether 'equals()' or '==' is the equality operator used.

ObjKeyTable(int)
Constructs a new, empty hashtable.
ObjKeyTable(int, int)
Constructs a new, empty hashtable with the specified initial capacity.
ObjKeyTable(int, int, boolean)
Constructs a new, empty hashtable with the specified initial capacity and comparison type.
ObjKeyTable(int, int, boolean, float)
Constructs a new, empty hashtable with the specified initial capacity and the specified load factor.

areEqual(Object, Object)
Returns whether or not the key Objects are equal based on useEquals.
clear()
Clears the hash table so that it has no more elements in it.
clone()
Creates a clone of the hashtable.
contains(int)
Returns true if the specified object is an element of the hashtable.
containsKey(Object)
Returns true if the collection contains an element for the key.
elements()
Returns an enumeration of the elements.
get(Object)
Gets the object associated with the specified key in the hashtable.
isEmpty()
Returns true if the hashtable contains no elements.
keys()
Returns an enumeration of the hashtable's keys.
noSuchKey()
Returns the number, reserved by the 'noSuchKey' construction argument, that should not be used as a value in this ObjKeyTable.
put(Object, int)
Puts the specified element into the hashtable, using the specified key.
rehash()
Rehashes the content of the table into a bigger table.
remove(Object)
Removes the element corresponding to the key.
size()
Returns the number of elements contained in the hashtable.
toString()
Converts to a rather lengthy String.
usingEquals()
Returns whether this ObjKeyTable is using 'equals()' for equality.

ObjKeyTable 
  public ObjKeyTable(int noSuchKey,
                     int initialCapacity,
                     boolean useEquals,
                     float loadFactor)
Constructs a new, empty hashtable with the specified initial capacity and the specified load factor.
Parameters:
noSuchKey - A reserved number that should never be used as a value. This number is then used to indicate that a key-value association was not found.
initialCapacity - the initial number of buckets
useEquals - whether to use the equals() method or '=='
loadFactor - a number between 0.0 and 1.0, it defines the threshold for rehashing the hashtable into a bigger one.
Throws: IllegalArgumentException
If the initial capacity is less than or equal to zero.
Throws: IllegalArgumentException
If the load factor is less than or equal to zero.
ObjKeyTable 
  public ObjKeyTable(int noSuchKey,
                     int initialCapacity,
                     boolean useEquals)
Constructs a new, empty hashtable with the specified initial capacity and comparison type.
Parameters:
noSuchKey - A reserved number that should never be used as a value. This number is then used to indicate that a key-value association was not found.
initialCapacity - the initial number of buckets
useEquals - whether to use the equals() method or '=='
ObjKeyTable 
  public ObjKeyTable(int noSuchKey,
                     int initialCapacity)
Constructs a new, empty hashtable with the specified initial capacity. 'useEquals' defaults to false, ie, '==' is the default equality operator.
Parameters:
noSuchKey - A reserved number that should never be used as a value. This number is then used to indicate that a key-value association was not found.
initialCapacity - the initial number of buckets
ObjKeyTable 
  public ObjKeyTable(int noSuchKey)
Constructs a new, empty hashtable. A default capacity and load factor is used. Note that the hashtable will automatically grow when it gets full. 'useEquals' defaults to false, ie, '==' is the default equality operator.
Parameters:
noSuchKey - A reserved number that should never be used as a value. This number is then used to indicate that a key-value association was not found.

usingEquals 
  public boolean usingEquals()
Returns whether this ObjKeyTable is using 'equals()' for equality. If it isn't, then it's using '==' instead.
noSuchKey 
  public int noSuchKey()
Returns the number, reserved by the 'noSuchKey' construction argument, that should not be used as a value in this ObjKeyTable.
areEqual 
  public boolean areEqual(Object one,
                          Object two)
Returns whether or not the key Objects are equal based on useEquals.
size 
  public int size()
Returns the number of elements contained in the hashtable.
isEmpty 
  public boolean isEmpty()
Returns true if the hashtable contains no elements.
keys 
  public synchronized Enumeration keys()
Returns an enumeration of the hashtable's keys.
See Also:
elements, Enumeration
elements 
  public synchronized Enumeration elements()
Returns an enumeration of the elements. Use the Enumeration methods on the returned object to fetch the elements sequentially.
See Also:
keys, Enumeration
contains 
  public synchronized boolean contains(int value)
Returns true if the specified object is an element of the hashtable. This operation is more expensive than the containsKey() method.
Parameters:
value - the value that we are looking for
Throws: NullPointerException
If the value being searched for is equal to null.
See Also:
containsKey
containsKey 
  public synchronized boolean containsKey(Object key)
Returns true if the collection contains an element for the key.
Parameters:
key - the key that we are looking for
See Also:
contains
get 
  public synchronized int get(Object key)
Gets the object associated with the specified key in the hashtable.
Parameters:
key - the specified key
Returns:
s the element for the key or the 'noSuchKey' construction argument if the key is not defined in the hash table.
See Also:
put
rehash 
  protected void rehash()
Rehashes the content of the table into a bigger table. This method is called automatically when the hashtable's size exceeds the threshold.
put 
  public synchronized int put(Object key,
                              int value)
Puts the specified element into the hashtable, using the specified key. The element may be retrieved by doing a get() with the same key. The key cannot be null, and the value cannot be the 'noSuchKey' construction argument.
Parameters:
key - the specified key in the hashtable
value - the specified element
Returns:
the old value of the key, or noSuchKey if it did not have one.
Throws: NullPointerException
If the key of the element is equal to null.
See Also:
get
remove 
  public synchronized int remove(Object key)
Removes the element corresponding to the key. Does nothing if the key is not present.
Parameters:
key - the key that needs to be removed
Returns:
the value of key, or noSuchKey if the key was not found.
clear 
  public synchronized void clear()
Clears the hash table so that it has no more elements in it.
clone 
  public synchronized Object clone()
Creates a clone of the hashtable. A shallow copy is made, the keys and elements themselves are NOT cloned. This is a relatively expensive operation.
Overrides:
clone in class Object
toString 
  public synchronized String toString()
Converts to a rather lengthy String.
Overrides:
toString in class Object
